column4: :( Hi, a USB Fat volume has a file with shebang to bash. Its context menu properties does not allow me to change file to be executable. I have the date of the last time it worked in Maverick. What is going on?
you need explicitly mount it with exec option
this is done recently?
try sudo udisks
that is not a gui command :(
linux has no useful gui
a couple of weeks ago I could stick the usb in, click on the .sh file, and the dialog would pop to allow me to vet the execution.
that should be still in
no longer works, it brings up option to open in text editor, instead of poping up the vetting dialog.
last time it worked Nov 10. The smalltalk image file was accessed
because you don;t own the volume
so how do I become owner of volume?
you specify it at mount time
God this is really lame, it should all be possible via the gui. How do I mount with permissions to execute?
remember that as soon as I stick the USB, it become mounted (I don't even know that the device is!)
you have to remount it via udisks giving corresponding options
is it black magic to know the the device, the udisks command and its options. God this is lame.
with exec option
tell me more
use 'mount' command to see what the deviace name for your usb is and then mount it 'udisks --mount DEVICE --mount-option rw,exec'
I don't recognize any of the `mount` output. I know the volume is named SAVES so it mounts from /media/SAVES
I found it - the confounded USB is '/dev/sdb1 on /media/SAVES type vfat (rw,nosuid,nodev,uhelper=udisks,uid=1000,gid=1000,shortname=mixed,dmask=0077,utf8=1,showexec,flush)'
does not accept 'sudo udisks --mount /dev/sdb1 --mount-option rw,exec'
does not accept 'sudo udisks --mount /dev/sdb1 --mount-option  rw,exec'
